title: Separatists kill dozens in weekend attacks in Pakistan | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The Pakistani province of Balochistan is reeling from a series of violent attacks on security forces by a separatist group over the weekend. The Balochistan Liberation Army (BLA) has claimed responsibility for the action, which killed nearly fifty security personnel and civilians. The Pakistani military says it killed at least 145 BLA militants in a 40-hour gun battle. The BLA has been fighting the government for decades, and the weekend's events mark one of the biggest escalations in years. Rebecca Johnston reports. title: "Too early to call it good news" - Rafah crossing reopens after two years | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The Rafah border crossing is now open to pedestrians leaving and entering the enclave. Tens of thousands of people are in need of medical care, but a limited number of people will be allowed to enter and leave the enclave each day. Oxfam policy lead Bushra Khalidi spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani and says uncertainty remains around who will be granted access to the crossing. title: Why Pakistan blames India for deadly violence in Balochistan | The World | ABC News
description: Pakistan's Prime Minister, Shehbaz Sharif has vowed to continue the war against terrorism, following a series of deadly attacks have that killed nearly fifty civilians and security personnel and saw 145 separatist fighters killed by Pakistani forces in the Balochistan region. The attacks have been claimed by the separatist group, the Balochistan Liberation Army, in a conflict that has lasted decades.   Pakistan accuses India of supporting the BLA, but New Delhi has repeatedly denied the claims.  So why has the conflict gone on for so long, what can we expect in the days and weeks to come?  Imtiaz Gul, executive director of the Center for Research and Security Studies Pakistan spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about Pakistan's struggles in the restive region.   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. title: India to lead new BRICS payment system to challenge US dollar | The World | ABC News
description: A crucial agenda item at the next BRICS summit in India will be the development of a BRICS payment system. It could build alternative payment rails to allow trade to be settled directly between national digital currencies, reducing reliance on the US dollar-based SWIFT system. For participating economies, the appeal is faster settlement, lower transaction costs, and reduced exposure to sanctions or asset freezes by western governments.   Alicia Garcia Herrero, chief economist for Asia Pacific at Natixis spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about how the system could work and challenge Western institutions and economies. title: Epstein files reveal ties to Andrew’s ex-wife Sarah Ferguson | ABC NEWS
description: The latest batch of released Epstein files has shed more light on the nature of the relationship between former prince Andrew’s ex-wife and the late convicted sex trafficker.  Sarah Ferguson appears to have shared a close connection with Epstein and even described him as a ‘legend’ a year after he was convicted of procuring a minor for prostitution, but the relationship subsequently deteriorated. Meanwhile, pressure is mounting on Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor to provide testimony in front of US congress. title: What's happening to the price of gold and silver? | ABC NEWS
description: The price of silver plunged 30 per cent over the weekend, and the value of gold also plummeted.  Business correspondent David Taylor spoke to some punters waiting for hours outside ABC Bullion in Sydney about why they're buying the precious metals Meanwhile in Perth last week, people waited for hours outside the Perth Mint to buy up gold and silver, as prices reached record highs. title: Unpacking the latest Epstein files | ABC News Daily podcast
description: There are three million files and thousands of mentions of Donald Trump.     But the US president says the latest batch of the Epstein files clears him, while the US Department of Justice says there’s no need for any further investigation.    But is that really the end of it?    Today, David Smith from the United States Studies Centre at Sydney University on what the latest files mean for Trump and others and why millions of documents are still hidden.    Featured:    David Smith, associate professor at the United States Studies Centre at the University of Sydney

title: Survival specialists teach key safety skills in Antarctica | ABC NEWS
description: A team of field training officers contracted by the Australian Antarctic Program are teaching Antarctic expeditioners key survival skills, safety training and how to conduct search and rescue operations. ABC's Jano Gibson got a first-hand look at the harsh conditions they're up against. title: Renewed search for Dezi Freeman enters second day | ABC NEWS
description: Victoria Police is entering the second day of a renewed five-day search for traces of alleged gunman Dezi Freeman in the state's northeast.  The search was prompted by a witness report of hearing a gunshot in the hours after two police officers were shot dead while trying to serve a warrant at Mr Freeman's Porepunkah home. title: Gazans frustrated at drip reopening of Rafah border crossing | ABC NEWS
description: The Rafah border crossing between Egypt and Gaza has reopened after two years of closure, allowing a limited number of injured and sick Palestinians to seek medical treatment on the other side.  Families and aid agencies have expressed frustration over a daily cap of 150 people to be allowed through, with approximately 20,000 Gazans in need of urgent medical attention.  The border crossing was supposed to open during the first phase of a Trump-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas, but Israeli authorities kept the gates shut due to a delay in the return of Israeli hostage bodies. title: Trump announces US-India trade deal, with New Delhi pledging to stop buying Russian oil | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump has announced a trade deal with India after a phone call with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi.  The White House will reduce tariffs on Indian goods from 25 per cent to 18 per cent effective immediately, while New Delhi pledges to purchase up to $US500 billion ($718b) worth of US products and cease buying Russian oil.  The Australian Strategic Policy Institute’s Dr Raji Rajagopalan says the move signals India’s alignment with the US because it cannot rely on Russia to deal with security threats from China. title: Endangered frogs released into ACT wild for the first time since the 1980s | ABC NEWS
description: The green and gold bell frog will be released into the wild in the ACT for the first time since the 1980s. Researchers at the University of Canberra have been breeding the species to withstand a deadly fungus that’s responsible for the decline and extinctions of amphibian species. Associate Professor in conservation ecology Dr Simon Clulow says it’s a surreal feeling to release the frogs after working on the species for almost 20 years.
